Award.AwardTitle: CIF:Small:Collaborative Research:Minimum Energy Communications in Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to answer a fundamental question in wireless networking: what is the energy needed to transmit one bit of information over a wireless network? And the related question: how can practical networks be designed to come close to this limit? The motivation is to save energy. It is evident that there is a strong current interest in energy conservation. Currently it is estimated that consumer electronics account for 11% of total residential electricity consumption in the US. While this is not all used on communications, as most devices have wireless capability, wireless communications could account for a significant part of this energy consumption. Clearly, if this energy consumption can be cut in half, the saving is significant. In fact, preliminary results show that by optimizing the signaling, energy consumption in wireless communications can be reduced much more than 50%.

As is well known, there are few networks where the exact Shannon capacity has been found. The research therefore approaches the theoretical part of this problem in different ways. For some networks, the minimum energy per bit can be found even if the exact capacity cannot be found. When the exact minimum energy per bit cannot be found, approximations to the minimum energy per bit are sought in the form of a figure within a certain number of dB that is universal over a certain class of networks. A key part of the research will be to look at networks with correlated information and distortion. Joint source-channel coding can reduce the energy consumption beyond what a separate approach can provide. The theoretical approach will be combined with practical coding methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energy consumption in wireless communications is a critical issue. On the on hand, from a consumer perspective, users want smaller devices with longer battery life, which can be approached through reducing energy consumption (which is one reason, for example, Apple designs their own chips). On the other hand, from a societal perspective, energy consumption of communications is becoming an increasing focus, under the banner of “green” communications. Apart from battery life, the reason is the impact on CO2 emission. An estimate is that information and communication technologies account for 2% of worldwide CO2. Also, recently there has been an increased awareness energy used in data centers, but a new report estimates that 90% of energy consumption in cloud computing is actually in wireless access, not in data centers.

The goals of this project is find fundamental, theoretical, limits of energy efficient transmission. Understanding these limits will enable design of future energy efficient wireless devices.

Intellectual merit:

The outcomes of the project are to find the exact energy consumption of several types of networks. A main impediment to wireless communications is interference from other user. To overcome interference, more energy has to be used for communications. A major result is that energy consumption in a system with many users is the same as that of a system with two users. Thus, there is an energy cost in going from one user to two users, but adding more users after that does not increase energy consumption. This surprising result is obtained by utilizing delays in communications creatively.

Broader impact:

The general understanding of energy consumption achieved through the project can lead to energy savings in wireless communications. Specifically, the results on energy and interference directly specifies a practical method for achieving energy savings. This might potentially be applied in satellite communications.

The project has educated two PhD students, of which one is a woman.
